definition[0]: a row of small bushes or trees growing close together, usually dividing one field or garden from another
definition[1]: something that protects you against possible problems, especially financial loss
example[0]: Buying a house will be a hedge against inflation.
definition[2]: to avoid giving a direct answer to a question
example[1]: You’re hedging again – have you got the money or haven’t you?
example[2]: ‘That depends on my partner, ’ she hedged.
definition[3]: something that gives you protection against a financial risk, for example FUTURES (=agreements to buy or sell currencies etc on a fixed date in the future at a fixed price) or OPTIONs (=rights to buy or sell currencies etc at a particular price within a particular period of time or on a particular date in the future)
example[3]: They decided that diesel fuel for the company’s trucks would rise by at least 10 cents a gallon, and have done some forward buying as a hedge.
example[4]: Investors often buy precious metals as a hedge against inflation.
definition[4]: if you hedge a financial risk, you protect yourself against it, for example with FUTURES (=agreements to buy or sell currencies etc on a fixed date in the future at a fixed price) or OPTIONs (=rights to buy or sell currencies etc at a particular price within a particular period of time or on a particular date in the future)
example[5]: I’ve never hedged currencies before. But I could see the dollar was getting lower, and I hedged for the first time, betting that the dollar would rise.
example[6]: Northwest Airlines saved more than $7 million in fuel costs because it hedged 4.2 million gallons of its fuel purchases for each month by buying futures contracts.
definition[5]: to reduce your chances of failure or loss by having several choices available to you
example[7]: Promoters, uncertain whether losing weight was going to stay popular, hedged their bets by advertising that their products could help you add weight or reduce it.
